nodes.text: Subjective, classroom-observation based teacher evaluation can cause lasting improvements in mid-career teachers' effectiveness (skill or effort) that increase student math achievement in years after evaluation

We study a quasi-experimental intervention: Cincinnati Public Schools Teacher Evaluation System (TES) where mid-career teachers were assigned a year-long observation-based evaluation in a phased schedule, allowing within-teacher before-during-after comparisons

Data: administrative CPS records 2003–2004 to 2009–2010 matched TES observation dates and scores to student-level standardized math test scores for 105 mid-career 4th–8th grade math teachers and 14,331 student-year observations

Mechanism assumption: evaluation provides individualized, salient information via rubric-based observations and feedback (including peer evaluators), prompting teacher learning, sustained effort, or both, which can translate into higher value-added

Main empirical claim: under teacher fixed effects identification, TES evaluation is associated with higher student math achievement during the evaluation year and larger gains in years after evaluation relative to the teacher's pre-evaluation years

Identification strategy: teacher fixed effects regressions of student standardized math scores on indicators for year of evaluation and post-evaluation years, controlling for grade-by-year fixed effects, student covariates, and a quadratic in teacher experience (capped)

Analysis sample construction: veterans hired 1993–2000 were phased into TES by hire-year schedule allowing pre-evaluation observations and reducing endogeneity of evaluation timing; sample limited to mid-career math teachers because test measures available

Result (during evaluation): students taught in a teacher's TES year score modestly higher in math (positive coefficient ~0.05 SD) though estimates during the year are less precisely estimated and not always statistically significant

Result (post-evaluation): students taught after a teacher's TES evaluation score about 0.11 standard deviations higher in math relative to students taught by the same teacher before evaluation (statistically significant)

Heterogeneity evidence: postevaluation gains are larger for teachers with lower pre-evaluation test-score value-added, for teachers with lower TES scores, and for teachers whose TES scores improved most during the evaluation

Robustness checks: event-study showing no clear pre-trend in years prior to evaluation, alternative functional forms (separate year dummies), use of scheduled-phase-in timing and 2SLS instrumenting actual timing with scheduled timing yield similar postevaluation effects

Attrition analysis: modest teacher attrition after TES year but most teachers remain; restricting to teachers observed before and after evaluation or weighting by inverse probability of remaining yields similar or larger postevaluation estimates, suggesting attrition is unlikely to explain main result

Limitation: data do not identify precise behavioral changes or disentangle learning from persistent effort responses; reading outcomes show no significant gains and generalizability may be limited to settings where individualized performance information is scarce or where peer evaluators are used

Cost consideration and trade-off: TES program incurred substantial direct costs (~$7,500 per teacher evaluated per year) and opportunity costs from using high-performing teachers as peer evaluators whose teaching slots are filled by less-experienced replacements; net benefits depend on number of teachers improved per evaluator

Conclusion: structured subjective evaluation can improve teacher human capital beyond sorting incentives; well-designed evaluation may serve as an effective form of professional development and could have implications for evaluation in other sectors
